data.title: All-time best Yankees by jersey number (1-33)
authors: Ryan Hatch | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
data.meta_description: How many can you guess right?
data.text:
Ryan Hatch | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com

Best Yankees by jersey #

Some of these, especially the single-digit numbers, you probably can already guess. (Like Mr. No. 2 pictured here, for instance.) But how about all of the teens, or the 20s?

See here for the best Yankees players to ever wear jersey numbers 1-33, the first of a three-part series we're rolling out this holiday weekend (34-67 on Sunday, 68-99 Monday). Hit the share button above to send to a fellow Yankees fan.

(Photo credit: Greg M. Cooper | USA TODAY Sports)

MLB

No. 1, Bobby Murcer

The outfielder played 13 seasons with New York, socking 175 home runs. He was an All-Star every year from 1971-'75.

MLB

No. 2, Derek Jeter

Need we say more? Jeter won five world championships with the Yankees in his 20 years as New York's shortstop.

MLB

No. 3, Babe Ruth

Ruth remains the most famous baseball player to have ever lived. His 714 home runs are third-most in history.

MLB

No. 4, Lou Gehrig

No other Yankee has ever worn No. 4. The Iron Horse played 17 seasons with the Yankees and hit 493 home runs. Gehrig's name will likely be remembered forever because of his association with the disease that killed himâ€”Lou Gehrig's disease, also known as ALS.

MLB

No. 5, Joe DiMaggio

DiMaggio, owner of a 56-game hitting streak, is a Hall of Famer who won three MVPs. He lost three seasons to World War II.

AP

No. 6, Joe Gordon

The Hall of Famer played seven years in New York (1938-1946) and slugged 153 home runs in that span. He was an All-Star six of those seasons.

MLB

No. 7, Mickey Mantle

Among the top-5 most famous Yankees ever, Mantle slugged 536 home runs in his 18 seasons with New York and won three MVPs.

MLB

No. 8, Yogi Berra/Bill Dickey

Berra won three MVPs and 10 World Championships with the Yankees from 1946 to 1965.

Dickey, also a Hall of Fame catcher, was an 11-time All-Star with the Yankees from 1928-'46.

The number is retired by the Yankees in both Berra's and Dickey's name.

MLB

No. 9, Roger Maris

In 1961 Maris broke Babe Ruth's single-season home run mark of 60, slugging 61, which stood until 1998 when it was broken by Mark McGwire. Maris played seven years in New York and won two MVPs.

MLB

No. 10, Phil Rizzuto

The Hall of Fame shortstop won an MVP in his 13 seasons with New York (he won in 1950) and would likely have put up even bigger numbers if he hadn't lost three years due to World War II.

MLB

No. 11, Lefty Gomez

The lefty (get it?!) pitched 13 seasons in New York and is in the Hall of Fame after posting a 3.34 ERA and winning 189 games.

MLB

No. 12, Wade Boggs

The Chicken Man made his name in Boston with the Red Sox but put up good enough numbers in four years with the Yankees to earn this spot. His ride around old Yankee Stadium on a horse after the 1996 World Series victory remains one of the most famous moments of that era.

MLB

No. 13, Alex Rodriguez

A-Rod, as you may know him, has 692 career home runs and 2016 is his 12th year in the Bronx. His legacy is complicated and controversial (he was suspended for the entire 2014 season because of a link to steroids), but he remains one of the best players to ever play the game.

MLB

No. 14, Curtis Granderson

Shockingly few Yankees have worn No. 14 and shined. Granderson played for the Yanks from 2010-2013 and smacked 115 home runs, finishing fourth in the MVP race in 2011. He's now the right fielder for the Mets.

MLB

No. 15, Red Ruffing

The Yankees have No. 15 retired in honor of Thurman Munson, but it was Ruffing who put together the more impressive career wearing the jersey. He won 231 games as a Yankee and his ERA was 3.47. He is in the Hall of Fame, having played a total of 22 years.

MLB

No. 16, Whitey Ford

Ford won the Cy Young in 1961 and finished his career, all in New York, with 236 wins and a 2.75 ERA.

MLB

No. 17, Mickey Rivers

Enos Slaughter may have worn No. 17 for longer but Rivers was better. Rivers hit 34 home runs in 3.5 years with the Yankees and finished in the MVP voting for three straight seasons from 1976-'78.

MLB

No. 18, Johnny Damon

Jersey number 18 doesn't produce a very rich history among Yankees players. Damon, who helped the Yanks win a World Series in 2009, tops the list.

MLB

No. 19, Dave Righetti

Righetti played 11 years in New York and was Rookie of the Year in 1981. He finished his career with 252 saves.

MLB

No. 20, Jorge Posada

You remember this guy. The Yankees retired Posada's No. 20 last year and the catcher, one-fourth of what's remembered as the "Core Fore" (Posada, Jeter, Andy Pettitte, Mariano Rivera), won four World Championships with the Yankees.

MLB

No. 21, Paul O'Neill

O'Neill manned right field for the Yankees from 1993-2001, part of four World Series championships. He 185 home runs as a Yankee.

MLB

No. 22, Roger Clemens

Clemens won two World Series with the Yankees (2000, 2001) and the AL Cy Young in '01. Clemens isn't exactly remembered fondly throughout baseball for his off-the-field drama tied mostly to steroids, but he's still the best Yankee to ever wear No. 22.

MLB

No. 23, Don Mattingly

Mattingly played 14 years in the Bronx, winning the MVP in 1985. Only in 1995, his last season, did the Yankees make the postseason during his tenure at first base.

MLB

No. 24, Robinson Cano

Cano played nine seasons in New York before bolting for Seattle after the 2013 season. While in New York Cano hit 204 homers and was a six-time All-Star.

MLB

No. 25, Mark Teixeira

You could argue No. 25 should go to Tommy John (91-60 in eight seasons), but Teixeria has hit 194 home runs with the Yankees and should eclipse 200 this season as long as this neck issue doesn't seriously plague the year.

Teixeira, of course, was part of the 2009 World Series team, his first year in New York.

MLB

No. 26, Orlando Hernandez

El Duque won three titles with the Yankees and finished his career with a 2.55 postseason ERA.

Drake Moffat | Twitter

No. 27, Butch Wynegar

Slim pickings for No. 27, but Wynegar put up some decent numbers from 1982-'86 with the Yanks, driving in 168 runs with a .368 on-base percentage.

MLB

No. 28, Sparky Lyle

From 1972-'78 Lyle saved 132 games and posted a stellar 2.50 ERA. A different time with less offense, sure, but still impressive. He won the Cy Young in 1977.

MLB

No. 29, Catfish Hunter

The Hall of Fame righty made his name in Oakland and won a three World Series there, but he wasn't bad in New York, winning 63 games '75-'79. He won two World Series with the Yankees, giving him five for his career.

MLB

No. 30, Willie Randolph

Randolph was a five-time All-Star with the Yankees in his 13 years here at second base. Randolph never hit more than seven home runs in a season but finished his career with 271 steals.

MLB

No. 31, Dave Winfield

The Hall of Famer clocked 205 home runs with the Yankees in nine seasons and went to 12 All-Star games in his career.

MLB

No. 32, Elston Howard

Not a lot of 32s from Yanks over the years, but Howard put together a nice career in the Bronx from 1955-1967. He hit 161 home runs as a Yank and won the MVP in 1963.

Howard was the Yankees first-ever black player.

MLB

No. 33, David Wells

Remember the perfect game? Come to Yankee Stadium and they'll be sure to remind you time, after time.
